headline.kicker: SUCCESSION IN MOSCOW: A PRIVATE LIFE, AND A MEDICAL CASE

docs.lead_paragraph: Konstantin U. Chernenko died of lung, heart and liver disease, according to an autopsy report signed by the chief Kremlin physician, Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, and nine other doctors. The 73-year-old Soviet leader's main medical problem was a common, incurable, chronic lung disease called emphysema. The strain of the emphysema, in turn, severely damaged Mr. Chernenko's heart, enlarging it, causing it to fail, and finally stopping it at 7:20 P.M. Sunday, according to the report. In addition, the report said, Mr. Chernenko's liver was destroyed by two common diseases, chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis. These liver disorders can have many causes, such as viruses, drugs or alcohol. The Kremlin doctors were not specific about the cause in Mr. Chernenko's case.

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. Irving J. Selikoff, whose research on occpational and environmental diseases led to a cure for tuberculosis and revealed the perils of asbestos dust, will retire in July as director of the Mount Sinai Medical School's environmental science laboratory. The physician, a resident of the Bergen County community of Ridgewood, said in a recent interview that he also would give up his teaching duties at the medical school, an adjunct of Mount Sinai Hospital on New York City's Upper East Side. However, he will continue his research at the laboratory, becoming once more the full-time researcher he was two decades ago, before assuming administrative responsibilities. ''Twenty years ago,'' Dr. Selikoff recalled, ''a friend and associate of mine said that the hospital was losing a very good researcher and getting only a mediocre administrator. I've been thinking over what he said, and decided he was right.''
